Introduction

Premature ejaculation is characterized by uncontrolled ejaculation and decreased ejaculatory latency (ie, time from penetration to ejaculation).  It can occur as an isolated symptom or in association with other sexual disorders (eg, erectile dysfunction).  The exact etiology is often unclear and treatment is only required if the condition causes distress for the patient and/or partner.  Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, which prolong ejaculatory latency, are often effective.

Physiology



Sexual arousal is the primary stimulus for tumescence (ie, erection), and repetitive penile stimulation eventually leads to ejaculation, a complex process that is coordinated by the central and peripheral (somatic and autonomic) nervous systems.  Ejaculation occurs in 2 phases:



  • Emission:  Sperm and seminal fluid are secreted into the prostatic (ie, posterior) urethra.
  • Expulsion:  Rhythmic contractions of the bulbospongiosus and ischiocavernosus muscles propel semen through the urethra and out the meatus.  This is typically when orgasm occurs.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



Premature ejaculation is a common sexual disorder characterized by ejaculation that occurs sooner than desired (either before or shortly after penetration), causing distress to one or both partners.  It is the most common sexual disorder in men age <40.



Premature ejaculation can be:



  • Primary:  Lifelong, present from the first sexual experience; often associated with an ejaculation latency time of <1 minute in the majority of patients.
  • Secondary (or acquired):  Occurs later in life after a period of normal sexual functioning, typically has a latency time <3 minutes.  Stressful life events may be a trigger.


The pathogenesis of premature ejaculation involves a complex interplay of neurobiologic, psychologic, and interpersonal factors:

Neurobiologic factors



  • Abnormal serotonin levels:  Serotonin receptor activation plays a role in inhibiting ejaculation; therefore, low serotonin level or serotonin receptor dysfunction has been associated with an increased risk of premature ejaculation.
  • Penile hypersensitivity:  Leads to overstimulation of the sympathetic pathways that control ejaculation, causing a hyperexcitable ejaculatory reflex.
  • Hormonal imbalance:  Low testosterone and prolactin levels are associated with premature ejaculation (though the exact mechanism is unclear because testosterone supplementation does not seem to improve function).
  • Erectile dysfunction (ED):  Coexists with premature ejaculation in up to 1/3 of cases. A patient's concern about the inability to maintain an erection during intercourse may precipitate premature ejaculation.
  • Chronic prostatitis:  Chronic inflammation of the prostate and surrounding structures may increase nerve sensitivity in the pelvic area and alter the normal coordination of muscles involved in ejaculation.
  • Medical comorbidities:  Hyperthyroidism is associated with premature ejaculation, possibly due to overstimulation of the sympathetic nervous system.

Psychologic/interpersonal factors



  • Mood disorders:  Anxiety, depression
  • Stressful life events and sleep deprivation:  Associated with abnormal serotonin levels/function
  • Relationship issues:  Conflict, performance anxiety, unrealistic sexual expectations
  • Lack of confidence:  Body image concerns, shame, feelings of unworthiness
  • History of sexual abuse

Clinical presentation



Premature ejaculation is characterized by:



  • Ejaculation that routinely occurs prior to the patient's and/or partner's wishes, typically within 1 minute of penetration (or similarly short durations for other forms of sexual activity).
  • Inability to delay ejaculation
  • Psychologic distress or interpersonal difficulties

Diagnosis



Premature ejaculation is a clinical diagnosis based on the clinical history of uncontrolled ejaculation that occurs sooner than desired.  It is important to take a comprehensive psychologic and sexual history, including inquiries about past sexual experiences (such as abuse), erectile dysfunction, life stressors, and mental health conditions that may be contributing factors.

Differential diagnosis



The time to ejaculation during intercourse varies widely from person to person, as do the expectations of how much time is adequate.  Premature ejaculation is typically characterized by ejaculation that occurs before one or both partners desire.  If intercourse is prolonged because the receiving partner has difficulty achieving orgasm, the other partner may ejaculate too soon.  This may not be premature ejaculation but delayed orgasm in the other partner.  Alternatively, if the receiving partner is able to climax relatively quickly and the time to ejaculation is prompt but adequate, this is not premature ejaculation.

Laboratory evaluation and imaging studies



Laboratory tests are not required to diagnose premature ejaculation but may be useful to identify underlying medical conditions that contribute to the issue.  These may include urinalysis and serum testosterone, prolactin, and TSH levels.



Imaging studies such as pelvic ultrasonography or pelvic/lumbar MRI are rarely indicated unless structural abnormalities (eg, mass), inflammatory conditions (eg, prostatitis), or neurologic problems (eg, spinal cord lesion) are suspected.

Management



Several treatment strategies that may improve ejaculatory control and latency.  Management often involves a multidisciplinary team that includes a primary physician, sex therapist, psychologist, and/or psychiatrist.

Pharmacologic therapies



  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs):  Sexual dysfunction, specifically delayed orgasm, is a well-established adverse effect of SSRIs.  When used in patients with premature ejaculation, SSRIs have been effective at prolonging ejaculatory latency.
  • Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) (eg, clomipramine):  Have SSRI-like activity and produce similar effects of delaying ejaculation, but TCAs have a higher risk profile (eg, arrhythmia).
  • Topical anesthetics:  Lidocaine-prilocaine cream applied to the glans before sexual intercourse reduces penile sensitivity and prolongs the time to ejaculation.
  • Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors:  Used for managing erectile dysfunction, which may resolve associated premature ejaculation.

Behavioral therapies



  • Start-stop technique:  Alternating stimulation and rest to delay ejaculation.
  • Squeeze technique:  Partner stimulates the penis until highly aroused, then applies firm pressure just posterior to the glans until the sensation of imminent ejaculation subsides.


With repetition, these techniques can help prolong the time to ejaculation.



Psychologic counseling with cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) can be used to address concurrent anxiety, mood disorders, and intimacy concerns.  In addition, couples therapy may improve communication between partners and address relationship issues.



Other interventions can include pelvic floor exercises, which are strengthening exercises to enhance ejaculatory control and decrease hyperexcitability, as well as providing reassurance and normalizing discussions about sexual health.

Prognosis



Premature ejaculation often causes significant psychosocial distress.  Shame and embarrassment about inadequate sexual performance can result in poor self-esteem, sexual dissatisfaction, relational discord, and depression.  Early and effective intervention improves sexual function, quality of life, and relationships.

Prevention



Prevention strategies include stress/anxiety management, effective communication with partners, regular medical evaluations, and counseling for psychologic problems.

Summary
